content:
When working on RefinedDiscrTree, I discovered a problem with the completeness of the discrimination tree. The issue is that isDefEq switches to withAtLeastTransparency .default on implicit arguments. But the discrimination tree always uses reducible transparency. This means that in the following example, exact? fails to find a match when unification in reducible transparency does succeed:

def MyNat := Nat

instance : Add MyNat := ⟨Nat.add⟩

example (a b : MyNat) : a + b = b + a := by
  -- exact? -- `exact?` could not close the goal.
  with_reducible refine Nat.add_comm _ _

The same goes for simp and type class search.

This seems to not be a big problem in practice, but with the RefinedDiscrTree, it is more likely to show up due to the use of labbeled star keys. I.e., unlike DiscrTree, RefinedDiscrTree will check that two implicit arguments are the same if that is required. And The above problem can then arise.

I've now added a fix so that RefinedDiscrTree switches to unfolding in the default transparency in these implicit arguments, but I don't know yet whether this is a good idea.
